title.text: The UPV-PRHLT Combination System for WMT 2010

abstractContent.text: UPV-PRHLT participated in the System Combination task of the Fifth Workshop on Statistical Machine Translation (WMT 2010).
On each translation direction, all the submitted systems were combined into a consensus translation.
These consensus translations always improve translation quality of the best individual system.

introductionContent.text: The UPV-PRHLT approach to MT system combination is based on a refined version of the algorithm described in, with additional information to cope with hypotheses of different quality.

In contrast to most of the previous approaches to combine the outputs of multiple MT systems (, which are variations over the ROVER voting scheme, we consider the problem of computing a consensus translation as the problem of modelling a set of string patterns with an adequate prototype.
Under this framework, the translation hypotheses of each of the MT systems are considered as individual patterns in a set of string patterns.
The (generalised) median string, which is the optimal prototype of a set of strings, is the chosen prototype to model the set of strings.

datasetContent.text: Experiments were conducted on all the 8 translation directions cz→en, en→cz, de→en, en→de, es→en, en→es, fr→en and en→fr.

Some of the entrants to the shared translation task submit lists of n-best translations, but, in our experience, if a large number of systems is available, using n-best translations does not allow to obtain better consensus translations than using single best translations, but raises computation time significantly.

datasetContent.text: Consequently, we compute consensus translations only using the single best translation of each individual MT system.

The number of running words is the average number of running words in the test corpora, from where the consensus translations were computed; the vocabulary is the merged vocabulary of these test corpora.
All the experiments were carried outwith the true-cased, detokenised version of the tuning and test corpora, following the WMT 2010 submission guidelines.
We will present translation quality results in terms of translation edit rate (TER).

TER is computed as the number of edit operations (insertions, deletions and substitutions of single words and shifts of word sequences) to convert the system hypothesis into the reference translation.
BLEU computes a geometric mean of the precision of n-grams multiplied by a factor to penalise short sentences.
